properties.areaDesc: Laramie, WY; Albany, WY; Carbon, WY; Platte, WY
properties.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued February 8 at 4:30PM MST until February 8 at 5:15PM MST by NWS Cheyenne WY
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Cheyenne has issued a

* Snow Squall Warning for...
Southeastern Carbon County in south central Wyoming...
Central Albany County in southeastern Wyoming...
Northwestern Laramie County in southeastern Wyoming...
Southern Platte County in southeastern Wyoming...

* Until 515 PM MST.

* At 430 PM MST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line
extending from 19 miles north of Iron Mountain to 6 miles northwest
of Bow River Campground, moving southeast at 25 mph.

HAZARD...Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Wind gusts
greater than 30 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Dangerous life-threatening travel.

*

This includes the following highways...
Interstate 25 in Wyoming between mile markers 38 and 75.
Interstate 80 in Wyoming between mile markers 262 and 309.

Locations impacted include...
Albany, Rock River, Chugwater, Bosler, Bordeaux, Brooklyn Lake, Sugar
Loaf Campground, Brooklyn Lake Campground, Libby Creek Campground,
Bow River Campground, Deep Creek Campground, Rob Roy Campground,
Centennial, Lincoln Park Campground, Iron Mountain, Nash Fork
Campground, Baldy Peak, Ryan Park Campground, Slater and Wheatland
Reservoir 3.
properties.instruction:
Reduce your speed and turn on headlights! During snow squalls, the
visibility may suddenly drop to near zero in whiteout conditions.

Serious injuries and deaths may result from people exiting their
vehicles during a snow squall. Drivers may not be able to see you or
to stop! If stopped on the roadway or involved in an accident,
quickly exit your vehicle move as far away from the roadway as
possible ONLY when it is safe to do so. Do not stand along or near
the roadway, since approaching vehicles may be unable to maintain
control.

CMAMtext: Snow Squall Warning til 5:15 PM MST. Sudden whiteouts. Icy roads. Slow down! -NWS
